verses.verse: Boast <S%H1984><s%> not yourself of to morrow; <S%H4279><s%> for you know <S%H3045><s%> not what <S%H4100><s%> a day <S%H3117><s%> may bring <S%H3205><s%> forth. <S%H3205><s%>
Let another <S%H2114><s%> man praise <S%H1984><s%> you, and not your own mouth; <S%H6310><s%> a stranger, <S%H5237><s%> and not your own lips. <S%H8193><s%>
A stone <S%H68><s%> is heavy, <S%H3514><s%> and the sand <S%H2344><s%> weighty; <S%H5192><s%> but a fool's <S%H191><s%> wrath <S%H3708><s%> is heavier <S%H3513><s%> than them both. <S%H8147><s%>
Wrath <S%H2534><s%> is cruel, <S%H395><s%> and anger <S%H639><s%> is outrageous; <S%H7858><s%> but who <S%H4310><s%> is able to stand <S%H5975><s%> before <S%H6440><s%> envy? <S%H7068><s%>
Open <S%H1540><s%> rebuke <S%H8433><s%> is better <S%H2896><s%> than secret <S%H5641><s%> love. <S%H160><s%>
Faithful <S%H539><s%> are the wounds <S%H6482><s%> of a friend; <S%H157><s%> but the kisses <S%H5390><s%> of an enemy <S%H8130><s%> are deceitful. <S%H6280><s%>

The full <S%H7646><s%> soul <S%H5315><s%> loathes <S%H947><s%> an honeycomb; <S%H5317><s%> but to the hungry <S%H7456><s%> soul <S%H5315><s%> every <S%H3605><s%> bitter <S%H4751><s%> thing is sweet. <S%H4966><s%>
As a bird <S%H6833><s%> that wanders <S%H5074><s%> from her nest, <S%H7064><s%> so <S%H3651><s%> is a man <S%H376><s%> that wanders <S%H5074><s%> from his place. <S%H4725><s%>

Ointment <S%H8081><s%> and perfume <S%H7004><s%> rejoice <S%H8055><s%> the heart: <S%H3820><s%> so does the sweetness <S%H4986><s%> of a man's friend <S%H7453><s%> by hearty <S%H5315><s%> counsel. <S%H6098><s%>

Your own friend, <S%H7453><s%> and your father's <S%H1><s%> friend, <S%H7453><s%> forsake <S%H5800><s%> not; neither <S%H408><s%> go <S%H935><s%> into your brother's <S%H251><s%> house <S%H1004><s%> in the day <S%H3117><s%> of your calamity: <S%H343><s%> for better <S%H2896><s%> is a neighbor <S%H7934><s%> that is near <S%H7138><s%> than a brother <S%H251><s%> far <S%H7350><s%> off.
My son, <S%H1121><s%> be wise, <S%H2449><s%> and make my heart <S%H3820><s%> glad, <S%H8056><s%> that I may answer <S%H7725><s%> <S%H1697><s%> him that reproaches <S%H2778><s%> me.
A prudent <S%H6175><s%> man foresees <S%H7200><s%> the evil, <S%H7451><s%> and hides <S%H5641><s%> himself; but the simple <S%H6612><s%> pass <S%H5674><s%> on, and are punished. <S%H6064><s%>
Take <S%H3947><s%> his garment <S%H899><s%> that is surety <S%H6148><s%> for a stranger, <S%H2114><s%> and take <S%H2254><s%> a pledge <S%H2254><s%> of him for a strange <S%H5237><s%> woman.

He that blesses <S%H1288><s%> his friend <S%H7453><s%> with a loud <S%H1419><s%> voice, <S%H6963><s%> rising <S%H7925><s%> early <S%H7925><s%> in the morning, <S%H1242><s%> it shall be counted <S%H2803><s%> a curse <S%H7045><s%> to him.
A continual <S%H2956><s%> dropping <S%H1812><s%> in a very <S%H5464><s%> rainy <S%H5464><s%> day <S%H3117><s%> and a contentious <S%H4066><s%> woman <S%H802><s%> are alike. <S%H7737><s%>
Whoever hides <S%H6845><s%> her hides <S%H6845><s%> the wind, <S%H7307><s%> and the ointment <S%H8081><s%> of his right <S%H3225><s%> hand, <S%H3225><s%> which denudes <S%H7121><s%> itself.
Iron <S%H1270><s%> sharpens <S%H2300><s%> iron; <S%H1270><s%> so a man <S%H376><s%> sharpens <S%H2300><s%> the countenance <S%H6440><s%> of his friend. <S%H7453><s%>

Whoever keeps <S%H5341><s%> the fig <S%H8384><s%> tree shall eat <S%H398><s%> the fruit <S%H6529><s%> thereof: so he that waits <S%H8104><s%> on his master <S%H113><s%> shall be honored. <S%H3513><s%>
As in water <S%H4325><s%> face <S%H6440><s%> answers to face, <S%H6440><s%> so <S%H3651><s%> the heart <S%H3820><s%> of man <S%H120><s%> to man. <S%H120><s%>
Hell <S%H7585><s%> and destruction <S%H10><s%> are never <S%H3808><s%> full; <S%H7646><s%> so the eyes <S%H5869><s%> of man <S%H120><s%> are never <S%H3808><s%> satisfied. <S%H7646><s%>
As the fining <S%H4715><s%> pot <S%H4715><s%> for silver, <S%H3701><s%> and the furnace <S%H3564><s%> for gold; <S%H2091><s%> so is a man <S%H376><s%> to his praise. <S%H4110><s%>

Though <S%H518><s%> you should bray <S%H3806><s%> a fool <S%H191><s%> in a mortar <S%H4388><s%> among <S%H8432><s%> wheat <S%H7383><s%> with a pestle, <S%H5940><s%> yet will not his foolishness <S%H200><s%> depart <S%H5493><s%> from him.
Be you diligent to know <S%H3045><s%> the state <S%H6440><s%> of your flocks, <S%H6629><s%> and look <S%H7896><s%> well to your herds. <S%H5739><s%>
For riches <S%H2633><s%> are not for ever: <S%H5769><s%> and does the crown <S%H5145><s%> endure to every generation? <S%H1755><s%>
The hay <S%H2682><s%> appears, <S%H1540><s%> and the tender grass <S%H1877><s%> shows <S%H7200><s%> itself, and herbs <S%H6212><s%> of the mountains <S%H2022><s%> are gathered. <S%H622><s%>
The lambs <S%H3532><s%> are for your clothing, <S%H3830><s%> and the goats <S%H6260><s%> are the price <S%H4242><s%> of the field. <S%H7704><s%>

And you shall have goats' <S%H5795><s%> milk <S%H2461><s%> enough <S%H1767><s%> for your food, <S%H3899><s%> for the food <S%H3899><s%> of your household, <S%H1004><s%> and for the maintenance <S%H2416><s%> for your maidens. <S%H5291><s%>
